subject: Psychological Safety is a Health and Safety Issue, and it’s Time We Treated It That Way
body:
The truth is: if people don’t feel safe to speak up, contribute, or challenge, they’re not truly safe.
 
 
Dear colleagues,
We hope 2025 has begun with promise and positivity for you and yours.
 
This year, the world is at a pivotal moment. As global headlines are dominated by significant political shifts, such as Trump's re-election, and corporate giants like META redefine their EDI commitments, the need for meaningful change has never been more urgent. It's time for organisations to take a hard look at their approach to EDI - evolving strategies and focusing more strongly on impact and actions that truly make a difference.
In this action-packed edition, you'll find: 
Why 
Psychological Safety is a critical Health and Safety issue
, and how to address it effectively
An invitation to our 
"Beyond SRA Compliance – Inclusive Leadership for a Thriving Culture"
 event
Exciting details about our 
International Women's Day
 workshops
Insights from our CEO in "
EDI Is Evolving - And It’s Time to Act!
"
A snapshot of our 
2025 predictions
 shaping the future of EDI
An opportunity to join our 
audiobook competition
!
 
Click on the links below to dive deeper into each topic.
 
As always, we’re here for any questions or additional information you may need.
 
Let’s make 2025 a year of real progress!
 
Warm regards,
Your 
Included
 Team 
  
Psychological Safety is a Health and Safety Issue - And It’s Time We Treated It That Way
When we talk about health and safety at work, we often think about physical risks - safety protocols, fire drills, and injury prevention. But there’s another critical element that’s often overlooked: psychological safety.
Psychological safety isn’t a "nice-to-have" or a soft issue - it’s a fundamental requirement for organisations that want to foster inclusion, retain talent, and build trust. And this is where Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI) comes into play.
 
Read now
 
Beyond SRA Compliance – Inclusive Leadership for a Thriving Culture
Join us for an exclusive free 60-minute, online event designed for HR and People professionals working in law firms and legal teams on Thursday 6 February 1200-1300 GMT.
 
The Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA) has set a clear mandate for accountability, inclusive practices, and cultural transparency. But are you leveraging these regulations to create lasting change and embed inclusive leadership at the highest levels?
Sign-up here
 
International Women’s Day 2025: Accelerate Action
In 2025, the world stands at a crossroads. With global headlines dominated by political shifts, such as Trump’s re-election, and evolving corporate strategies like META and Amazon’s reshaped DEI commitments, there’s a pressing need to accelerate tangible action on gender equity. This year’s sessions focus on equipping organisations and teams to navigate these challenges while advancing a bold, urgent vision for equity.
 
Find out more
 
EDI Is Evolving - And It’s Time to Act!
With recent events focusing attention on Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI), 
Included’s
 CEO, Michelle Sequeira, encourages you to take a step back and consider the bigger picture.
Resistance to progress is nothing new – history shows us that meaningful change is often met with pushback. From civil rights movements to LGBTQIA+ rights, every major shift has faced challenges. But these challenges are proof that change is happening...
 
Read more
 
Predictions for EDI in 2025
Here we look ahead to predictions for 2025, including areas such as AI and data analytics, pay equity and transparency, sustainable ESG, global EDI standardisation and many others.
  
Read more
 
The Key to Inclusion Audiobook
 
We are delighted to share that our book, 
The Key to Inclusion
, is soon to be available in audio format. This book, written in 2022, is a practical guide to Diversity, Equity and Belonging for You, Your Team and Your Organisation. Recognising the importance of diversity, belonging and equity is not enough and this book has the practical guidance needed to think differently and make true inclusion a reality.
To mark this exciting moment, we are offering you the chance of winning a free audio book code. Please visit the below link for further information. Good Luck!
Find out more
 
Find out more about 
Included
’s approach to diversity 
here
 and take a look at our 
Impact Report
. 
Please 
get in touch
 with us anytime to have a conversation about making your organisation more diverse and more inclusive.  We look forward to hearing from you. 
From all of us at 
Included
 
 
 
You are receiving this email because you subscribed to the 
Included 
email newsletter. 
Included 
is committed to ensuring the security and protection of all data we process. For more information on how we use your data, read 
our privacy policy
. 
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can 
update your preferences
 or 
unsubscribe from this list
Copyright © 2025, Frost Included, trading as Included. All rights reserved.

subject: Workplace Equity Weekly | Expanding Your Pay Equity Analysis
body:
Why you should go beyond gender and race in your pay equity analysis.
 
Workplace Equity Weekly
January 30, 2025
BLOG
Going Beyond Gender and Race In Your Pay Equity Analysis
Consider including disability in your pay equity analyses to ensure compliance with U.S. and European Union legislation. Learn how Trusaic’s software supports you.  
READ NOW
 
 
Key Resources
Pay Equity Deep Dive Series
Level up your pay equity knowledge with Gail Greenfield’s comprehensive blog series. Each blog provides actionable strategies you can apply at your organization. 
 
ACCESS NOW
 
Global Pay Transparency Center
Access comprehensive pay transparency guides for 50+ jurisdictions. Simplify compliance and meet regulatory requirements worldwide.
 
ACCESS NOW
 
Webinar
 
From Job Evaluation to Pay Equity: A Global Approach to Compliance
WATCH NOW
 
Survey Participation
2025 State of Pay Equity Policies and Practices
Our 2025 pay equity survey is now open for participation. This survey is looking to glean insights about how your organization approaches pay equity. It should take 15 minutes to complete and you will receive a complimentary copy of the results.  
Participate Now 
 
Trusaic, 520 S Grand Ave, Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90071, United States, 213-382-1115

subject: We Can't Talk About That at Work!
body:
Don’t Wait: In 2 weeks, this program kicks off! Learn how to handle polarizing topics with confidence and turn roadblocks into breakthroughs
 
In today’s divided and fast-changing world, the need for inclusive, productive conversations has never been greater. Yet, addressing polarizing topics at work—race, religion, politics, or other sensitive issues—can feel overwhelming.
 
That’s why we’re offering 
We Can’t Talk About That at Work! Mastering the Art of Polarizing Topics
, a transformative program starting in just
 
2 weeks!
 
In this 3-session series, you’ll gain:
Practical tools
 to manage emotions, de-escalate tension, and navigate tough topics
Proven frameworks
 from the bestselling and award-winning book 
We Can’t Talk About That at Work!
Real-world strategies
 to foster empathy, mutual understanding, and collaboration
Exclusive Bonus:
 
Sign up for all three sessions and receive a 
FREE digital copy of the Second Edition of 
We Can’t Talk About That at Work
!
 
Seats are limited
, and time is running out to secure your spot for the first session on February 12. Don’t miss this opportunity to invest in skills that will set you apart in navigating today’s challenges. 
Register for one or all three sessions here.
 
Yours Inclusively,
Mary-Frances Winters, Founder and CEO
Mareisha N. Winters Reese, President and COO
 
Register Now for This New Series
 
Don't let divisive issues become roadblocks. Invest in building stronger, more resilient professional relationships today when you register for either one or all of these sessions.
Session 1: Managing the “I” in Inclusive Conversations, February 12, 2025 
Session 2: Talking About Differences with Humility, February 26, 2025 
Session 3: Bridging the Divide for Mutual Understanding, March 12, 2025
 
Whether you register for one or all three, each session stands on its own, offering effective frameworks and strategies to build your skills and confidence in navigating tricky conversations. The full series was developed to be an active learning experience with each session building upon the last. 
Based on the award-winning and bestselling book 
We Can’t Talk About That at Work! How to Talk About Race, Religion, Politics, and Other Polarizing Topics
 
by 
Mary-Frances Winters 
and 
Mareisha N. Reese
, this program couldn't be more timely.
 
Seats are limited - register now!
 
 
 
 
 
The Winters Group, 8116 South Tryon Street, Ste. B3-260, Charlotte, North Carolina 28273, United States 
Unsubscribe
 
Manage preferences

subject: Is your tech stack holding you back?
body:
Transform recruiting outcomes with smarter tech
 
Hi Larry,
 
Today’s talent tech stacks are supposed to accelerate recruiting, but more often, they’re slowing teams down. High costs, scattered tools, and ineffective strategies are creating roadblocks instead of solutions. 
 
Join us for our first Talent Leaders Forum, 
Leveraging Technology for Better Recruiting Outcomes
, where Shane Noe, Marilyn Pearson Hendricks, and Ben Eubanks will explore how to optimize, consolidate, and future-proof your talent tech stack. 
 
In this roundtable, you’ll learn
: 
How to recognize and prevent tech overload 
The critical role of IT in making your tech stack smarter
Real-world examples of tech stack optimization
Don’t miss this opportunity to gain actionable insights and prepare for the future of talent acquisition. 
 
 
Subscribe to our newsletter
 for insider tips on trends, 
events, and more—delivered straight to your inbox!
 
Carefully crafted with ❤️ by Findem
Findem, 702 Marshall Street, Redwood City, California, 94063, United States
Unsubscribe

subject: 🛠️ Master the Art of Nonverbal Communication Across Cultures
body:
Continue reading to master the art of nonverbal communication across cultures ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Larry!
 
💡
 
Ready to turn silent misunderstandings into meaningful connections?
 
 
🔗
 Let’s Recap: 
In my last email, we uncovered a silent challenge: misreading or ignoring nonverbal cues in culturally diverse organizations. 
These subtle signals—eye contact, gestures, tone of voice—carry significant meaning. But when they’re misinterpreted, they can lead to disengagement, tension, and missed opportunities to create a truly inclusive culture. 
The good news? With the right strategies, you can unlock the power of nonverbal communication to foster understanding and connection. 
 
🛠️
 Actionable Strategies to Bridge the Nonverbal Gap 
1️⃣ 
Educate Your Team on Cultural Differences
Host training sessions that focus on how nonverbal cues vary across cultures. For example, some cultures see direct eye contact as a sign of confidence, while others view it as disrespect. Building awareness is the first step to creating empathy and reducing misinterpretation. 
 
2️⃣ E
ncourage Curiosity, Not Assumptions
Train employees to approach nonverbal cues with curiosity rather than judgment. A simple question like, “
I noticed you were quiet in the meeting—what are your thoughts?
” can uncover valuable insights and show respect for cultural norms. 
 
3️⃣ 
Practice Active Observation
Teach your team to tune into patterns of nonverbal behavior rather than isolated actions. This helps avoid jumping to conclusions based on a single moment. Patterns provide context and reveal a deeper understanding. 
 
4️⃣ 
Model Inclusive Nonverbal Behavior
Leaders set the tone. Encourage managers to use open body language, welcoming gestures, and active listening cues. These small shifts can create a more inclusive atmosphere where employees feel seen and respected. 
 
5️⃣
 
Incorporate Feedback Loops
Regularly check in with employees to understand how communication styles are impacting their experience. This feedback ensures that cultural nuances are recognized and addressed over time. 
 
🌟
 Imagine the Impact: 
Picture this: 
Meetings where diverse perspectives flow effortlessly because everyone feels understood. 
A team culture rooted in mutual respect and curiosity about one another’s unique ways of communicating. 
A workplace where nonverbal signals strengthen, rather than strain, collaboration. 
This is the power of cultural competence in action. 
 
📅
 Let’s Build This Together: 
Want tailored strategies to help your team navigate the nuances of nonverbal communication? Schedule a 
complimentary call
 with me today. Together, we’ll design a roadmap to bridge the cultural communication gap and empower your workforce. 
 
👉
 
Click here to schedule your complimentary call.
 
 
Here’s to creating workplaces where every gesture matters! 
 
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by Mastering Cultural Differences 
1350 Sextant Avenue West • Roseville, MN • 55113-3134

subject: Re: Gap & payments
body:
OK thank you!
From:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Wednesday, January 29, 2025 2:29 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Gap & payments
 
 
At this point, the back pay is most important to me. After that is paid, I can discuss GAP, Feb. 11
th
, and Group M or whoever. But, the back pay is the priority for me. 
 
From:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, January 29, 2025 1:02 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Gap & payments
 
Ok thanks & yes, in addition to.
 
One other option - which I know does not solve your problem of the money owed to you - is that we delay your termination from LCW until after the Gap training & possibly until after the Feb.11th webinar.
 
At this point, would you be willing to even stay on another week or two to deliver these & still get paid a salary?
 
I would of course try to get you the money owed to you as well, but as you know can't promise anything.
 
Thank you!
 
From:
 Larry Baker <
l.baker@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Wednesday, January 29, 2025 1:57 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Gap & payments
 
 
Nicole, 
 
The $500 would have to be in addition to the $4,490.96. 
 
Now for the 60 sessions for Group M, I would need to see how that number would work for me with any other financial resources I will try to seek to receive from other sources (Unemployment). We can table all of that until you find out about GAP.
Thanks,
 
LBJ
 
From:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, January 29, 2025 12:49 PM
To:
 Larry Baker <
l.baker@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Gap & payments
 
Hi Larry,
 
Thanks for the candid chat today. I'm going to find out as much as I can asap.
 
FYI, if you were to get paid the money owed to you & would do the Gap training on Feb.5, we would offer $500 for the Gap session.
If you end up doing the BSC sessions (which I believe are 3 hours, and there are about 60 of them), we could offer you $500 per, totaling around $30,000. 
 
Talk soon!
Nicole
 
Nicole Barile
 
(She/Her)
Chief Operating Officer
LCW
